33358365.review:
A great game for the young or young at heart, and in its own way, a sad testament to how the adventure genre has declined.

After playing Primordia and Loom with my five year old, I set out to find another suitable adventure game.  Pajama Sam's reviews have the unfortunately quality of seeming like ironical memes, so I was somewhat skeptical when grabbing them.  I'm glad I overcame my trepidation because the series -- particularly the first game -- is excellent.

Basically, Pajama Sam is a pared-down point-and-click with wonderfully animated Saturday-morning-cartoon graphics and a story pitched at young children.  Despite the game's being aimed at children, there is enough cleverness in the writing -- and strangeness in the world -- that an adult can enjoy its content.  

While Pajama Sam is "pared down" in comparison to Monkey Island and King's Quest V, it is considerably more complicated than most of what passes for adventure games today.  The world is larger; the puzzles are more varied (employing a mix of inventory, logic, and observational puzzles); and there is a generous helping of the kind of extra content familiar from old games: the rooms are full of hotspots that provide amusing interactions.  

The game also has a host of optional content, and every time you play the world is slightly randomized, with certain puzzles only appearing in certain games, certain areas having different significance, and certain items being moved about.  This is an odd choice because the game is not particularly replayable and there is no choice in which puzzles you get -- you might play again and have the exact same distribution of content and items -- but it is an interesting novelty all the same.

In short, this is a lovingly made and endearing game perfectly suited for kids who are learning to love adventures.  It would make an excellent entry point to the genre, one that would set them on the path of the puzzle-oriented classics, rather than in the direction of the narrative-choice model that currently prevails.

After playing the games I can only say - what a shame that I didn't have them as a kid! I'm positive I would fall in love with them, because they have everything you want from a kids' game - a good message, funny and memorable characters (especially Sam who's just the cutest kid ever), an environment you can interact with, minigames and, surprisingly, very smart sense of humour. If you have children, I stongly recommend that you play Pajama Sam series with them, and if not - just try it yourself, it may very well return you to your own childhood. It sure did that for me.

31763183.review:
It was nice experiencing this little gem from my childhood again.

If you like point-and-click adventure games, especially the kind of surreal ones, where practically anything and everything is clickable, get this game! I was really worried that this game wouldn't hold up as well, playing it as an adult, but I can say that I still enjoyed the humor and the characters. Some of the animations might be a little dated, but what do you expect it's from 1996 (God I'm old). I had so much fun, I might just check out the other Pajama Sam games that are now available, as this was the only one I played as a kid.

Pajama Sam: NNHWIDO has basically an Alice in Wonderland-type story. Pajama Sam gets transported to the Land of Darkness through his bedroom closet, and goes on a journey through the land to vanquish Darkness, the character whom the land is so aptly named after. It's pretty simple, but that's really all it needs to be. The real focus is the humor and characters and both are just filled with so much charm. There's the boat who's afraid of water, the old mine car who's become rusted to the tracks, and the (literal) wishing well, who makes wishes when you throw him a penny. Yeah, this game's pretty weird, but that's what makes it so fun.

Like I said earlier practically everything in the game reacts to you clicking it, usually in more ways than one. One item may have multiple comedic reactions to you clicking on it. Seriously try and click everything in this game, even stuff in the background that just looks like it's part of the environment. I discovered some clickables playing the game now, that I never found as a kid.

This game also has surprising replay value. There will often be different parts of the environment generated in future playthroughs that replace some from previous playthroughs. These add more to the game; more jokes, more story, more characters.

Even if you aren't a kid check this game out, it's still pretty entertaining as an adult, plus it's fairly priced. It kind of reminds me of watching some of the old Cartoon Network shows I grew up with as a kid, it may be kind of old, but it's still fun. Check it out if you've got 7 dollars to spare.

29893609.review:
TODAY it seems to me providential that Fate should have chosen Braunau on the Inn as my birthplace. For this little town lies on the boundary between two German states which we of the younger generation at least have made it our life work to reunite by every means at our disposal.
German-Austria must return to the great German mother country, and not because of any economic considerations. No, and again no: even if such a union were unimportant from an economic point of view; yes, even if it were harmful, it must nevertheless take place. One blood demands one Reich. Never will the German nation possess the moral right to engage in colonial politics until, at least, it embraces its own sons within a single state. Only when the Reich borders include the very last German, but can no longer guarantee his daily bread, will the moral right to acquire foreign soil arise from the distress of our own people. Their sword will become our plow, and from the tears of war the daily bread of future generations will grow. And so this little city on the border seems to me the symbol of a great mission. And in another respect as well, it looms as an admonition to the present day. More than a hundred years ago, this insignificant place had the distinction of being immortalized in the annals at least of German history, for it was the scene of a tragic catastrophe which gripped the entire German nation. At the time of our fatherland's deepest humiliation, Johannes Palm of Nuremberg, burgher, bookseller, uncompromising nationalist and French hater, died there for the Germany which he loved so passionately even in her misfortune. He had stubbornly refused to denounce his accomplices who were in fact his superiors. In thus he resembled Leo Schlageter. And like him, he was denounced to the French by a representative of his government An Augsburg police chief won this unenviable fame, thus furnishing an example for our modern German officials in Herr Severing's Reich.
In this little town on the Inn, gilded by the rays of German martyrdom, Bavarian by blood, technically Austrian, lived my parents in the late eighties of the past century; my father a dutiful civil servants my mother giving all her being to the household, and devoted above all to us children in eternal, loving care Little remains in my memory of this period, for after a few years my father had to leave the little border city he had learned to love, moving down the Inn to take a new position in Passau, that is, in Germany proper.
In those days constant moving was the lot of an Austrian customs official. A short time later, my father was sent to Linz, and there he was finally pensioned. Yet, indeed, this was not to mean "res"' for the old gentleman. In his younger days, as the son of a poor cottager, he couldn't bear to stay at home. Before he was even thirteen, the little boy laced his tiny knapsack and ran away from his home in the Waldviertel. Despite the at tempts of 'experienced' villagers to dissuade him, he made his way to Vienna, there to learn a trade. This was in the fifties of the past century. A desperate decision, to take to the road with only three gulden for travel money, and plunge into the unknown. By the time the thirteen-year-old grew to be seventeen, he had passed his apprentice's examination, but he was not yet content. On the contrary. The long period of hardship, endless misery, and suffering he had gone through strengthened his determination to give up his trade and become ' something better. Formerly the poor boy had regarded the priest as the embodiment of all humanly attainable heights; now in the big city, which had so greatly widened his perspective, it was the rank of civil servant. With all the tenacity of a young man whom suffering and care had made 'old' while still half a child, the seventeen-year-old clung to his new decision-he did enter the civil service. And after nearly twenty-three years, I believe, he reached his goal. Thus he seemed to have fulfilled a vow which he had made as a poor boy: that he would not return to his beloved native village until he had made something of himself.
His goal was achieved; but no one in the village could remember the little boy of former days, and to him the village had grown strange.
When finally, at the age of fifty-six, he went into retirement, he could not bear to spend a single day of his leisure in idleness. Near the Upper Austrian market village of Lambach he bought a farm, which he worked himself, and thus, in the circuit of a long and industrious life, returned to the origins of his forefathers.
It was at this time that the first ideals took shape in my breast. All my playing about in the open, the long walk to school, and particularly my association with extremely 'husky' boys, which sometimes caused my mother bitter anguish, made me the very opposite of a stay-at-home. And though at that time I scarcely had any serious ideas as to the profession I should one day pursue, my sympathies were in any case not in the direction of my father's career. I believe that even then my oratorical talent was being developed in the form of more or less violent arguments with my schoolmates. I had become a little ringleader; at school I learned easily and at that time very well, but was otherwise rather hard to handle. Since in my free time I received singing lessons in the cloister at Lambach, I had excellent opportunity to intoxicate myself with the solemn splendor of the brilliant church festivals. As was only natural the abbot seemed to me, as the village priest had once seemed to my father, the highest and most desirable ideal. For a time, at least, this was the case. But since my father, for understandable reasons, proved unable to appreciate the oratorical talents of his pugnacious boy, or to draw from them any favorable conclusions regarding the future of his offspring, he could, it goes without saying, achieve no understanding for such youthful ideas. With concern he observed this conflict of nature.
As it happened, my temporary aspiration for this profession was in any case soon to vanish, making place for hopes more stated to my temperament. Rummaging through my father's library, I had come across various books of a military nature among them a popular edition of the Franco-German War of 1870-7I It consisted of two issues of an illustrated periodical from those years, which now became my favorite reading matter It was not long before the great heroic struggle had become my greatest inner experience. From then on I became more and more enthusiastic about everything that was in any way connected with war or, for that matter, with soldiering
But in another respect as well, this was to assume importance for me. For the first time, though as yet in a confused form, the question was forced upon my consciousness: Was there a difference -and if so what difference-between the Germans who fought these battles and other Germans? Why hadn't Austria taken part in this war; why hadn't my father and all the others fought?
Are we not the same as all other Germans?
Do we not all belong together? This problem began to gnaw at my little brain for the first time. I asked cautious questions and with secret envy received the answer that not every German was fortunate enough to belong to Bismarck's Reich..
This was more than I could understand.

29329011.review:
Ok, so I'll start with the pros and end with the cons.

Pros:
- Very immersive, I almost feel as though I was fighting darkness myself.
- Deep plot lines make for very fleshed-out and relatable characters.
- The art style is quite grand, and makes scenes appear larger than they really are.
- The combat system is very unique, and to some extent could be considered revolutionary for its time.
- The variety of game modes provides hours upon hours of nonstop action and entertainment.

Now, onto the cons:
- Very clunky multiplayer, I found myself struggling to connect with my friends even through LAN.
- The inventory system is cluttered and confusing, making it hard to find the item you're looking for.
- The lack of hints in the game makes some battles seem impassable, I've spent ages grinding up my skills for one fight and upgrading my gear to its max to no avail.
- On the contrast, some later-game battles seem to easy, where it feels as though all of the time you dumped into grinding is worthless

Overall, I give this Action RPG a 7/10, the game provides much entertainment and has enough variety to keep casual and competitive players in the action for as long as possible. The community is large and loving and is willing to show you the tips and tricks to maximize your gaming experience. Pick up a copy of Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside on the steam platform to witness a revolutionary gaming experience that changed the way devs thought for years.

29210872.review:
Literally one of the best point and click games of all time.
Of course, this game this meant for young children(I played it endlessly as one)so how could this be?
Pajama Sam finds that increasingly rare line where children's entertainment is balanced with subtle wit and humor that appeals to adults. A lot of the humor in the game I really didn't catch until I was older due to it's clever word play. I would go so far as to call this the Disney of point and click games.

The story is simple; yet very charming. Every character is interesting and full of personality. More personality than I would say a lot of current gen games have. The other thing that makes this so great is that Sam can interact with a lot of the characters, typically in multiple ways. The continuations of the dialog may not always serve a purpose, but it is definitely entertaining!

The puzzles in this game are pretty basic, yet satisfying. Nothing is ever really unclear and if you missed something or messed up, it's because you didn't look closely enough. There are, however, a few multistep puzzles that can get tricky if you aren't paying attention. I think it goes without saying that all of the puzzles are geared towards kids, so if you want something that won't be too difficult for them, this is a great choice. Definitely not as challenging as some of the Spy Fox ones were.

The other highlight of this is game is that is truly does look wonderful! To be honest, I don't really feel that the art has aged too much here. It's still incredibly vibrant and Humongous did an exceptional job in making sure that every screen really has a unique feel to it, which makes it easy to remember where you have and have not been.

Maybe I wear the nostalgia goggles when it comes to this game, but it was an absolute blast when I was a kid and I still go back to enjoy it now.

Thanks Humongous.

25404772.review:
There are too many reasons why this game is THE BEST game that you could ever buy on steam.

There is so much that I can say about this game, but I will talk about the best aspects of the game. 

The open world aspect of this game is incredible. From scene to scene, each area has something new to see and experience, from throwing pennies in a well to finding gold in the mines. It isn't a straightforward gaming experience, you can take your time and not be bugged by AI characters constantly telling to you move on with the game. 

Along with the main storyline, there are THREE amazing minigames to play throughout The Land of Darkness:

1. The Brain Tickler: This minigame isn't much of a "minigame" as it is more of a game that you can experience along your way throughout the main in-depth storyline that is "Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside". This game contains extremely hard multiple-choice questions such as "How is a star formed?", and even harder "What color is an orange?". These are extremely difficult questions that you will have to endure to be able to get to a certain area in the diverse open world of The Land of Darkness.

2. Cheese and Crackers: An extremely difficult minigame that consists of a 3x3 board where you play a toaster in a game of "Cheese and Crackers", a game where you must get 3 cheeses in a row before he gets 3 crackers in a row, taking turns placing down a cheese (you) and a cracker (the toaster). There are also other board sizes that you will be able to play on, but before you can even play the game, you must [spoiler]traverse the long and complex labyrinth that is the mines in order to find the gold mine, mine out the gold you find there with the pickaxe you picked up along the way, and give the gold to the toll-man that blocks your way to get to the Cheese and Crackers lounge.[/spoiler] There is no game in the world that can compare to this one.

3. Remote Mining Terminal: Quite possibly the best minigame within a game of all time. In this minigame, you take control of a minecart picking up gems in a grid, and each time you pick up a stone, the cart behind you increases. It is an extremely complex game to explain in text, you have to play it in the actual game.

The storyline goes as follows: Sam is about to go to bed for the first time without his big-boy night light, but gets scared of the dark, as we all do. You must then take it upon yourself to turn into... [i]PAJAMA SAM![/i] You enter your closet to find that is The Land of Darkness, a magical land filled with toys and socks that Darkness lives in. However, you are stopped by the customs trees, which take your stuff that you must find to be able to defeat darkness. You go on a long and dangerous journey through The Land of Darkness, making lots of friends, such as a boat and a minecart, to help you find your extremely important items: a flashlight, a limited edition all metal Pajama Man lunchbox, and your mask. I will not spoil the difficult steps you must take to get said things, as each playthrough the items are in a different area, providing you replayability like there's no tomorrow.

In addition to all of this, the game comes at the price of only $6.99, an extremely low price for what you are earning in the end. I definitely recommend that you pick this game up, as there isn't another game like this with quite the content and replayability as this. 

I rate this game 20/20 socks, a game to end all games.

23508656.review:
Pajama Sam is a Humongous point and click adventure game released during the mid 90s. It was the third series Humongous made after Putt Putt and Freddi Fish, and proved to be one of the most successful. Today it's well regarded as one of the best games that the developer ever made, and for being one of the very first games Jeremy Soule of Elder Scrolls fame worked on.

The premise is Pajama Sam is a child who is afraid of the dark. Inspired by his favorite comic book hero Pajama Man, he decides to journey into his closet to combat "Darkness". He finds himself trapped in "the Lands of Darkness". Where he must find his belongings and finally confront Darkness. What I like about the story is it has this very epic feel to it but the entire story is framed as being part of a child's imagination. The "lands of darkness" resemble Mordor but are littered with things you'd find in a closet like socks and lunchboxes. Moreover Pajama Sam himself is a very likeable protagonist who grows as a character over the course of his journey and it has a very nice somber ending.

Much like other Humongous games Pajama Sam also contains random elements. The locations of all of Pajama Sam's missing gadgets are randomized every playthrough. Meaning what locations are mandatory varies from playthrough to playthrough. This makes the game much more replayable, albiet to compensate for the general short length of the game. Alongside that the game has collectables in the form of socks that you can locate throughout the game. This was so well recieved that Humongous would later create a puzzle game devoted to this.

Among all of Humongous's games the Pajama Sam trilogy remains one of my favorite. It's one of my favorite adventure games and I've replayed it several times. It has a blend of polish that is very rarely seen in games even today, and I dearly recommend it to fans of children's games and fans of games that tell a good story.

23465633.review: THIS GAME OH MY GOODNESS, nostalgic af and it was beautiful. You assist sam on his quest to end the life of the oh so evil Darkness. You play mini games in the park and take rides on an abandoned mine cart with rusted wheels. Good family fun????

23340341.review:
Sam is a little boy fan of a super-hero. However, tonight, it's the first time he'll sleep without the light. He really wants to do it but he's afraid of Darkness, a evil enemy. So, he turns into Pajama Sam, a super-hero and is resolved to capture his nemesis so that he can sleep without fear....

Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside is a game aimed at children: it's a point-&-click adventure, with minigames in it, though they're not all needed to advance. The story can also speak for the little ones: it's showing Sam willing to sleep without light and getting over his fears. Kids can relate to him.

But to manage to do so, Sam is living an extraordinary adventure: he looses his flashlight, lunchbox and mask because trees are stealing them and before confronting Darkness, he needs to find them and retrieve them. Sam will have to show for example to Otto the boat that wood is floating, to oil the wheels of the wagon, etc..

What I realized is that the game is random: indeed, you have each time two possible locations for the items and so, a different solution for them (for example, the mask was with the carrot, I had to free the carrots in the fridge to get it - however, the mask would have been in the dance room, I would have made an invisibility potion). And I also liked the fact that you can choose your path in the mine. It means that you can find new locations, useful or not depending the "storyline" thrown at you. And as you're also in a quest to retrieve all socks in the game, some of them are there - be quick to click on them as Sam will not stop at them.

There is a minigame where you need to answer questions. And while one of them is tied to Darkness's domain, the others are about culture. However, I don't know if knowing how much fuel does a space shuttle need is pertinent. It's something very specific. Other questions were more general like the artist having paint Mona Lisa or the dinosaurs. There are also a Tic-Tac-Toe with crackers and cheese, a Snake-like game, a music room where you can hear several tunes, a laboratory where you can make many potions, ...

While I found the gameplay nice, Pajama Sam is also a testimony of its era: the '90. Indeed, in educational games or in children games, you tend to throw a lot of information. Big Thinkers, from the same developers/publishers, if you remember my review, were also full of items you can click and look at a special animation. Many easter eggs are also included: you can find Freddi Fish and Luther, Putt-Putt and Pep, characters from the same house.

Another thing is a testimony of the '90: the graphics themselves. However, contrary to Big Thinkers, Pajama Sam seems to have less aged. The soundtrack is also good.

The good surprise was the fact that the game is in French (and support other languages). It means that children will not need adults to translate or help them understand a foreign word. While the adults are still needed for anything else, it's a burden in less for them, particulary if they're not fluent at all with English.

But there is a little problem too: the inventory is showing itself by putting the cursor at the bottom of the screen. It's how you can find the menu too. There is no main menu, no tutorial about the keys to use, etc.. I had to search in a forum how to save, after having to exit the game and come back later - no progress was saved. I don't know if I was expecting it to be saved as in Big Thinkers but the lack of a profile was my first clue to that. So if you need to save and load, press S and L. It's apparently something related to the system used so that the game can run on recent machines.

Pajama Sam is really a good little moment for both children and adults. It may also be an help to get over fears. If I look into the second title, it's about thunders, so, I suppose that Pajama Sam was conceived to help children understand that some of their fears can be conquered. Anyway, if you search for a good children games, Pajama Sam should be considered to be in your list.

22311110.review:
Story: One of the most well known aspects of Pajama Sam is it's story; it is simply unorthodox, as it does the process of not feeding all of the story the viewer; it drip-feeds it, giving the viewer only half the story, or sometimes giving scenes without any context. For some games, this would be a disaster waiting to happen, but in the case of Pajama Sam, this is done almost consistently masterfully, holding back information on such subjects such as the location of the flashlight or what color an orange is. Many have critisized the holding of frames later in the series, but taken into the context of the fact they were running out of money to make the game, is is understandable.

For many fans, their major criticism of the game is the handling of the ending, which many consider far too 'out there' and simply crap. I too, am not a huge fan of the ending, but taking the ending to the game, inside the context of the 'true' ending sequel, Pajama Sam 3: You are what you Eat from your Head to your Feet, the ending can make a lot more sense, and thus I enjoy it far, far more. To stop me from ranting on for ages, Pajama Sam's story is a master stroke in writing, one which has been a hard feat to replicate.

Art and Sound: I was introduced to Pajama Sam through the in-progress tetraology of games, The Rebuild of Pajama Sam; due to this, I became used to the cutting edge graphics employed for the higher-budget games. And to be honest, yes, the original game's art is beginning to show it's age 20 years on; however, this does not detract from the series in any major capcity, as the art compliments the anime extremely well.

The sound is also fantastic, and a very high-point for the show. Excellent music is employed to showcase the chaos of finding your lost socks, and for darker moments such as the internal struggles of the main cast of the game. Some of Beethoven's music is featured later in the series, which coupled with the emotional impact of the scene, produces one of the most excellent scenes in video game history.

Characters: By a massive leap, the highlight of the series. Pajama Sam features in it's story the struggles of the main characters, to devastatingly wonderful effect. Weak, timid, daddy-issues Sam, to powerful, arrogant, egotistical Mom, to the quiet, mysterious Boat, and the brooding, apparently agnostical Darkness, Pajama Sam develes into the mind and motivations of these characters, showcasing exactly what makes them tick, and this is what gives us some of gaming's most regonisable and wonderful characters.

I am certain entire essays have been written on why certain charcters tick, and that's another reason so many of these characters are so wonderful. Fans are so devoted to their favorite characters (personally I am partial to Mom and Boat), and this creates a wonderful feeling when learning about these characters and then discussing this with other fans. Generally, Pajama Sam employs some of the most human characters in games, showing us that the heroes of gaming aren't always strong, both mentally and physically, or not even in control of their lives.

In closing, Pajama Sam is one of the strongest games ever produced. It employs powerful characters, a deep, deep story, and art that has only just began to show it's age. What makes the game's longevity even more powerful is that even now on sites such as PJSamGeeks people are still analysing this series, trying to know everything about it. I hope Pajama Sam will live on in the hearts of it's fans, who'll continue to appreciate it's deep, metaphorical story. I hope that Pajama Sam will always remain an game that will be treasured, for all the ages.

Ich habe durch englische Videos auf YouTube viel über dieses Spiel gehört. Für einige Leute ist es *DAS* Spiel ihrer Kindheit. Als es hier auf Steam entdeckte, sogar mit einer deutschen Übersetzung, griff ich zu.
….Vielleicht werden irgendwann mal meine (nicht englisch sprechende)  Kinder von diesem Spiel genau so schwärmen, dachte ich mir.

Ich lud es runter, startete es und.... 
meine Ohren begannen zu bluten!
Wer bitte hat die deutsche Synchronisation verbrochen????!??

Der Mensch, der den Sprecher  vom Hauptcharakter  "Pajama Sam" (oder wie er auf Deutsch heißt: "Pijama Piet" *ächtz*) zugelassen hat, gehört schnellstens gefeuert! Denn er hat den größten Stümper gecastet, den ich je das Missvergnügen hatte zu hören!
Jede einzelne Zeile klingt als würde sie ein Erstklässler von einem Zettel ablesen. Doch anstatt sich mühe zu geben, wird dafür jeder einzelne Satz besonders laut gesprochen….oder besser gesagt geschrien. Von der Stimmlage hingegen hört es sich so an, als wäre Sam/Piet von einer 50-jährigen Frau synchronisiert worden, die ihre Stimme verstellt um mehr wie ein Kind zu klingen.

Im englischen Original haben wir hier, laut YouTube, ein fantastisches Adventure für Kinder, darum bezieht sich meine Bewertung ausschließlich auf die Synchronisation, denn das gesamte Spiel wurde dadurch schlichtweg ruiniert.

Meine Bewertung: 1/10

18980884.review:
People who have seen me tear games like Borderlands and Republic Commando to shreds (games with larger fanbases), might be expecting me to do the same to a much smaller game that no one really remembers, but as far as personality, good game design, and storytelling go- Pajama Sam is one of the better examples out there.

I know what you're thinking. "Dude? For real? You're favorite games are The Last of Us and Spec Ops: The Line! Those games are INTENSE! And you're suggesting a kid's educational game from the 90's belongs up at the top of the list with some of the greatest games ever?" 

In my opinion? Yeah.

See, Pajama Sam was a game DESIGNED for kids, but the developers had enough mind to add enough humor that only adults would get. I'm not saying there are any sex jokes, and there aren't, but there are plenty of jokes that I know would go over most kids' heads. The game is also much more maturely designed. Of all of the Humongous Games, you mainly are told specifically what to do (Spy Fox, Freddi Fish), or you meet completely foolish characters that tell you what they need but are more than capable of getting the job done themselves (Putt Putt). But Pajama Sam did something different... it plays with empathy. Think about it. You run into situations, and mainly Sam reacts to the situation or you- the player- does. Otto can't go out on the river, just as he can't move along the land since he's a boat. The King can't move because he's rusted to the track. For the few seconds you speak with each character, you feel sorry for their problems (mainly Otto's stupidity) and solve them yourself.

The game also does incredibly well with it's design. The artwork is beautiful to look at, and the way each frame is shot to emphasize different perspectives and imply you can move in different directions makes the game very clear and concise. It's not like some point-and-click games where you stumbled across a door fifteen times and didn't notice it till you looked up the FAQ on the game. And, yes, the game is simple. It is easy. But, like I once told my ex, it doesn't have to be hard to be good. The voice acting is decent. as are all the sound effects, and the music is very ambient and creates a lively atmosphere.

The game revolves around a large puzzle for one of your three lost items, and each item has two randomly-selected puzzles that can be mixed and matched any which was, creating a lot of different "games" for you to play through. Of course, I got each different puzzle for the missing items after playing three times. But with this, and the 20 missing socks you can find, Pajama Sam could take up roughly 2-3 hours for you to play in its entirety, where you can take 40 minutes of your day to sit down and relax to the Land of Darkness.

Pajama Sam may not look like much, but of all the old point-and-click games I've played as a child, this one certainly has a lot more substance to it. There were the second and third official ones (we don't talk about the fourth), but the first one really got a strong identity for the character of Pajama Sam and his world of imagination. It's no masterpiece, and I'll never try to sell it like it is, but it is really, really, really good. It's a lot better than a lot of games I've played out there. Granted, it may not be for everyone, but it still is worth checking out for anyone looking for a very unique video game.

18788087.review:
This game right here is the first one I ever owned, and I couldn't resist picking it up again. Just like I remember it, the game is an excellent point-and-click adventure, one that you can play over and over thanks to the main 3 items randomly changing locations. I always loved this feature, because every time you start anew, you have to solve different puzzles to beat the game, rewarding each replay with variety. Sure, I hold this game on the nostalgic pedestal a bit, but not without good reason. 
   Now about the Steam version: I'm a bit disappointed. I've ran my original copy in the Scumm engine before and reached the same performance differences here: voice dialogue loads faster then normal, so characters talking in cutscenes sound like they don't take a break to breathe and just go into the next sentence. Here and there I see animations changed or cut out altogether, particularly during the intro dialogue with King where he says "Loop-de-Loops" and his face doesn't move. The game is still fully playable, but these emulation problems still got to me. It would be unreasonable to recommend getting an original copy and seeing for yourself, as this game was designed for Windows '95 and the like; the game would most certainly not work without a virtual machine. Even still, if you remember this game, played it or not, this purchase it still worth it.

Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside is undoubtedly one of the greatest games ever made. This point-and-click adventure is filled to the brim with things to point and click at, putting all other PC games to shame with their comparitively low levels of point-and-click content. Naturally, I can't talk about this game without bringing up its incredible story: the amount of effort Humongous Entertainment put into this story, starring a happy-go-lucky child confronting his deepest fears, should be enough to earn the company a Nobel Prize in literature. With its brilliant cast of characters - including an anarchist carrot, pseudo-intellectual trees and a boat who doesn't understand his true purpose in life - this game is sure to contain at least one character that any player can relate to. With its combination of unique storytelling, complex gameplay and mature themes, I can say with conviction that no gamer's life is complete if they haven't played this first installment in the Pajama Sam series.

And if that isn't enough to convince you, let me just summarize my previous statements with this: 10/10 WOULD PLAY AGAIN.

15496598.review:
Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside is a point and click adventure game for kids with a few educational aspects thrown in. The plot is based on a comic that the main character, Pajama Sam, reads. He is on a mission to venture into his closet and defeat darkness so he won't have to be afraid of the dark anymore. You mainly click around to go to different screens and explore. You can talk to other characters, pick up items, and click on various parts of the environments as well for reactions or clues. And key locations of items are changed between playthroughs, giving it a few different ways to play. There's a lot of voicework in the game, with many characters having multiple dialogues for continued clicks. There's also a good amound of music and lots of sound effects to help go along with the colorful, cartoon style. You'll need to use a bit of problem solving for getting items and figuring out where to use them. There are even a few minigames to try out. Plus, there's a side quest for the more adventurous players to try and collect 10 pairs of socks. The socks are hidden throughout the game so you'll have 20 to try and spot as you search the screens of the game. It's a nice little touch for some extra challenge. Oh, and some of the humor is actually pretty good.

However, there are problems with this game. While there are many things to click on in any given location, a majority of them are simply there as goofy asides. There are typically a variety of different reactions for each item, but all they do is distract you from the main game. They don't really add much atmosphere, instead generally being there to keep kids entertained. It makes sense, sure, but it's not really something I'd call good game design, regardless of the target audience. There are even a few parts that don't have any real point to them, depending on which random set of circumstances the game gives you on your playthrough. Sometimes areas will have things to interact with but no reason to do so. Not that the extra bits aren't nice for a little more world there, or possibly an area to house a sock or two, but they don't feel necessary enough to include without looking at it as padding just a little bit. There also doesn't seem to be much reason to get all the socks. Not that there NEEDS to be a reward, and possibly there is as I missed a few, but it seems like the game just ends and doesn't really give you much incentive to go get them other than just wanting to do it for yourself. 

Overall, it's a surprisingly solid game. I just randomly won it in a giveaway and figured it was going to be some lame kids' game. It actually isn't too bad. It could do more, do some things better, and be more challenging... but I understand its for kids that would probably spend more time figuring it out as it is. I didn't grow up with this game. I'm not blinded by nostalgia. I just thought it was genuinely a nice little experience. My only gripe is that it costs 7 bucks. That's a bit steep for this game, unless you're actually getting it for a kid. If you're getting it to check it out and you're not a kid, especially considering it's on Steam, then you're better off waiting for a sale to get it for only a few bucks. I wouldn't say it's worth full price, but if you're curious, it IS worth checking out. Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside gets a 6 out of 10 for being an older game for kids that has held up over the years, even without the nostalgia.

15017200.review: Pajama Sam was one of the most recognizable computer game characters while growing up during grade school. I never had the chance to play this game as a kid, but I would of loved it had I actually did. The game was made by Humongous Entertainment, a company known for their educational/family oriented computer games. The plot is simple: a boy named Sam is afraid about sleeping in his own room with the lights out but instead of fearing it, he decides to overcome his fear by "defeating" Darkness as "Pajama Sam". He travels to his closet when he "visits" Closet Land to find Darkness. The characters are very lively and there's never a dull moment within the game. Plus Sam is voiced by the talented Pamela Adlon(Dewey from Quack Pack, Lucky from 101 Dalmations TV series, Ket from Kiki's Delivery Service, & Jue and Manabu from Animatrix). The Closet Land is a cross between The lands of Living Island, Oz, & Wonderland where anything can come to life just by clicking on it. There's also some mini games that will keep you busy for a few hours. Overrall Pajama Sam is a wonderful game for any kid to play as well as those who are young at heart.

14831410.review:
Many many years from now I will be sitting down with my grandson/daughter and I'm going to put them on my lap. I will be 60 years old, and a single tear will roll down my cheek. It will ask, "What's wrong Grandpa?". And I am going to say that in my long years, no game even came near the sheer greatness of Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside. 

The story is a sprawling epic about a small child overcoming his fears and becoming the hero he was always destined to be. The theme of destiny is forced throughout the 200 hour experience. 
The characters are perfect and accurate examples of real life people that no game has ever achieved nearly as well as this one did. 
The puzzles. Those puzzles have haunted me all my life as being some of the best to ever exist. 

I will say to my grandson/daughter, "You will never play a game that is nearly as good as Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside. Never ever."

If you are a fan of puzzles, story, beautiful graphics, top-notch level design, or even just games in general. Hey even if you aren't a fan of games, drop money right now for this gift from God himself. 
Do yourself a favor, play this game...and just never stop. Never.

13810422.review:
Whatever the reason, be it the sense of the unknown, the dulling of the sense we tend to rely on most, or some other more inherent instinct, at some point we've probably all shared a fear of the dark and what might be lurking in it. My solution to this was pulling the covers over my head and sleeping with the lights on, but I suppose I didn't have a surreal world living in my closet like Pajama Sam so I couldn't very well head out and attempt to capture darkness in my lunchbox.

Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside is the blanket garbed, flashlight wielding protagonist's debut and one of the few Humongous games I never got a chance to play as a kid. And that's a bit of a shame as it might possibly be the best written, most logical and entertaining series the studio put out in their edutainment boom.

Characters are lively and over the top, with clever writing and a lighthearted sense of humor that makes them delightful to interact with. The twisting art is somewhere between a haunted house and an Escher painting and still looks fantastic even with the original low resolution, clearly distinguishing between items you can pickup and packing a lot of charming little touches into almost every nook and cranny.

This certainly isn't the most challenging (or possessing any challenge whatsoever for that matter), but its simple puzzles are no less fun to solve and helping Sam and his friends overcome their feels is all kinds of heartwarming. Perhaps I'm simply biased toward all of Humongous's catalog, even those I never played, but whatever the case the hour or so I spent with NNtHWIDO (oof, that's some acronym) was a rather surprisingly entertaining bit of breezy adventure gaming, and I'm now eager to see what Sam's future endeavors have to offer.

13337683.review:
Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside - Raymond KT

I loved Pajama Sam growing up; I and my brother would just adore this classic. Beat it again and again and made us smarter in a way. Pajama Sam: No Need To Hide When It's Dark Outside is the most cleverly written children's game I've ever played. It also looks charming, has a great soundtrack, and three different routes each time you start from the beginning. It's enjoyable for kids and adults, and you won't regret giving it a try.

A key element for any children’s adventure game is voice acting – if the performances aren’t engaging, it’s likely that interest will be lost quickly. Thankfully, every moment you spend with these characters is a delight thanks to the brilliant and varied voices. Ranging from Sam’s high and chirpy voice to Otto’s hesitant and slightly wary style to the quiz show door’s enthusiastic zeal, each actor injects a highly distinctive personality into their respective roles. The music complements this perfectly, with upbeat tunes keeping the mood light while mixing in the occasional chime to add an unearthly air. Music even takes part in the game itself, with furniture dancing in secret and kitchen appliances singing about their functions.

The trees are just a sample of the unusual characters that will make an appearance. Sam is the only human (if you can call him that) in this world, an innocent and friendly young boy who is keen to assist others. Along the way he’ll encounter a toaster, a coat stand and a fridge, to name but a few of the everyday items that have come to life. The most memorable are Otto the boat and King the mine cart, both of whom you’ll help out with their troubles. They act as modes of transport, and thus you’ll spend more time connecting with them than anyone else. It’s a shame other minor characters don’t play a bigger role, because everyone has a unique personality (such as the carrot trying to rescue his friends from being used in a salad and the over-worked water well) and I’d have liked to interact more with this colourfully assorted cast.

Ages ago, a game about a young boy with a skin disease and odd hair growth set out to fight Darkness. 

Pajama Sam is actually quite simple. You may need to spend some times figuring out the controls, but it's easy once you get the hang of it. The game isn't that long either. You can get through it in about 2 hours or less without even trying that hard. But, Pajama Sam has an old school sense of humor. (Read: Actually funny.) Unlike other kid games or movies that are just dumb, Pajama Sam can be actually funny, with a great attention to detail. 

Even though the game graphics are WAY out of date and you can see the pixels, it still has an odd charm. 

Pajama Sam is the only game in which you can lead a carrot rebellion, answer questions about World Leaders, and beat a toaster in a game of Tic-Tac-Toe. 

I recommend it if you can spend some money on a VERY short game. And if you want more milleages out of it? Maybe you should livestream it. I'm sure a lot of people will have a good laugh.

9996659.review:
[u][b]Truly the epitome of videogames.[/b][/u]
The story is jam-packed with exciting plot-twists, intuitive humour, and the most perfect of nicks and crannies here and there.
The character design is flawlessly filled to the brim with heart and effort, as with the enchanting voice acting from every character you meet.
Fortunately, each and every character is unique and is flowing with personality, even Pajama Sam's mother is an absolute hoot to see in-game.
The music is so perfectly fitted in game, and can be enjoyed for hours upon hours of looping. I could go as far to say that I could honestly hear this music playing in a Queen album, and I have said such things.
The art in this masterpiece was truly before it's time, with backgrounds and sprites so elegantly drawn, you could mistake them for levels in a PS4 game, and it would have to be a superb PS4 game.

I honestly cannot say a single bad thing about this game, it is the portrait of perfection, just as all the other brilliant works of Humongous Entertainment, though, this one takes the cake. Pajama Sam is without a doubt, the most atmospheric, challenging, hilarious, thrilling experience you will ever face in life, you will see the face of your first-born child sleeping in your arms, and you will think "Man, I should be playing Pajama Sam right now".
I highly suggest playing this game late in your life, because once you finish this, you will have felt every single level of every single emotion ever existed and more, nothing will ever satisfy your new-found standards after playing this love-child of beauty and genius.

Buy this game.
10/10
Better than The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time.

7.5/10 for quality.
9999999999999999/10 for nostalgia.
HAVARTI





If you were a child in the '90s or early '00s, you probably remember this game, if you played it before, get ready for an amazing nostalgia trip, if not, this game is still fun.

This is a point-and-click adventure game that was released for the PC in 1996 (so graphics may seem somewhat dated, but still hold up very well) in which you play at the titular hero Pajama Sam in his adventures through the amazing world inside his closet (imagination...?). He is trying to conquer his fear of darkness and defeat the physical representation of him with his special flashlight and lunchbox, but trees steal them almost as soon as you enter the closet. You must find your lunchbox and flashlight, help a boat conquer his fear of water, help a minecart get unrusted, collect as many sockas as you can, and play some cheese and crackers along the way.

This game also changes up its world a lot in each playthrough, objects may be in different places and different problems may need to be solved, making for great replay value.

Click on everything you can for bizarre things to happen...

Note:
this game is relatively low in difficulty as it is designed for those of young age, so don't be so surprised if you find yourslef finishing this game very quickly.

9903694.review: As a young kid, I played Putt-Putt and Freddi Fish, but I actually hadn't played Pajama Sam, although I wanted to.  Playing this game for the first time as a twenty-year-old, I can say I thoroughly enjoyed it.  The target audience may be six-year-olds, but there are many jokes and references thrown in that I don't think I would've gotten back then.  There were points that got a pretty good laugh out of me.  Some of the puzzles can also be fairly challenging, even if you are an adult.  The story is great and even though the game is pretty short, there is plenty of replay value with the sock collecting and the fact that certain items are in different locations in each playthrough.  Also, that mine cart minigame is pretty fun in short bursts and gets very challenging.  If you didn't grow up with the Humongous point-and-click games, then I'm not sure whether or not you would find this game enjoyable.  However, for those who did, I think you should check or re-check this game out.  Unlike some of the other Humongous games from the 90's, I think this one has stood the test of time and is definitely worth a download.

9896195.review: This is probably one of the greatest games ever made. Chronicling a young boy's hallucinations as he descends into insanity, this game provides an unforgiving look at the dark side of human nature. It explores concepts that other games are simply unwilling to touch such as the dark side of capitalism (the bridge), police brutality (the trees), and humanity's desire to destroy what it does not understand (Sam's quest to defeat darkness). In an age of big budget games that err on the side of political correctness and mass appeal, this classic title is truly a breath of fresh air.

With mask on face, and flashlight and lunch box in hands, even Darkness is no match.

My view of this game is certainly biased by the nostalgia factor, but it's still a great game for a young child to play through. The content is humorous, the world is filled to brim with imagination, and the story will certainly entertain.

That aside, the only difference I noticed in this version compared to the CD release was the addition of subtitles. I think the subtitles were added because the audio is unusually poor for the dialogue, but it's certainly still understandable (though the subtitles are poorly implemented). It has a bit of a static background to it. You can also pause the game entirely with the Spacebar.

That aside, this game is perfect for the nostalgia factor, or for a young child.

9862194.review: This is an incredibly spooky game that requires loads of brain power. As a little kid, I never realized how spooky this game was until now. Darkness is probably the best boss battle I've seen, but be warned, do not play this game alone in the dark. You must have good observation skills to locate all of Sam's socks and you also make new friends along the way like Otto the boat who has a negative outlook on life and a cool accent. Try not to rage when the purple dancing couch doesn't get off your mask though. Not only is this game a spooky and fun past time, but I also learned about gysers and physics. Pajama Sam weighs less than 3 rocks so we needed 3 rocks in the opposite basket to lift Sam in his basket to get us into the house that Darkness lives in. I'm confident in physics now thanks to this game! From learning strategies like getting a slab of wood with a rope to mining gold in a much more fun way than Minecraft, this is a fun game to play, despite how scary it gets at times. 12/10 would play again.
